update.description:
This PR adds Hermite and Laguerre polynomial bases with sparse differentiation. The Hermite node/weight construction from scipy uses Townsend’s asymptotic formulas so works for any size. The Laguerre node/weight construction fails above N ~ 256. Both bases use pre-weighted recursions in float128 to construct the basis functions.

Potential improvements:

* Better Laguerre node/weight construction for larger sizes
* Add multiplication matrices to enable NCCs? Can this be done sparsely?
* Potentially add explicit recursions for computing derivatives \(Laguerre is dense\).
update.title: Hermite and Laguerre bases

content.raw: NCC multiplication between enveloped and non-enveloped functions implemented.
content.html: NCC multiplication between enveloped and non-enveloped functions implemented.

content.raw: Option to add tau pre or post preconditioning has been added.
content.html: Option to add tau pre or post preconditioning has been added.

content.raw: Ability to use non-enveloped Hermite and Laguerre polynomials is now possible via the metadata “envelope” key.  Everything is supported except NCC expansions still need to be sorted out.
content.html: Ability to use non-enveloped Hermite and Laguerre polynomials is now possible via the metadata “envelope” key. Everything is supported except NCC expansions still need to be sorted out.

Potential improvements:

* Potentially add explicit recursions for computing derivatives \(Laguerre is dense\).

content.raw: Also we might want to add an option to let you drop a row before or after preconditioning, since it seems like you have to do it before to get good results with Laguerre \(this sort of makes sense – doing it after is adding a tau term like generalized laguerre L^\(1\)\_\(N-1\), which projects against all L\_n equally…
content.html: Also we might want to add an option to let you drop a row before or after preconditioning, since it seems like you have to do it before to get good results with Laguerre (this sort of makes sense – doing it after is adding a tau term like generalized laguerre L^(1)_(N-1), which projects against all L_n equally…
